author: Reuters Editorial
title: No joint written statement after end of latest NAFTA talks: sources
text:
MEXICO CITY (Reuters) - The latest round of talks to revamp the North American Free Trade Agreement will conclude without a joint written statement from the United States, Canada and Mexico, like the last round, two sources with knowledge of the matter said on Monday.
U.S. chief negotiator John Melle is pictured at the hotel where the seventh round of NAFTA talks takes place in Mexico City, Mexico March 4, 2018. REUTERS/Ginnette Riquelme Canadian Foreign Minister Chrystia Freeland, Mexican Economy Minister Ildefonso Guajardo and U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer are due to make separate statements to the media at a joint event later on Monday, the sources said.
The latest talks, which began in Mexico City last week, have been clouded by U.S. President Donald Trumpâ€™s plan to impose tariffs on steel and aluminum imports. Canada and Mexico have threatened retaliation unless they are exempted.
Reporting by David Ljunggren and Lesley Wroughton; Writing by Julia Love; Editing by Paul Simao
